title: Intermittent JSON RPC
body:
#### System information

Geth version: (this spans two versions of geth 1.7.0 and 1.7.1, see below for more background)
```
Geth
Version: 1.7.1-stable
Git Commit: 05101641455a754936acc5ddff92f35f5e33181c
Architecture: amd64
Protocol Versions: [63 62]
Network Id: 1
Go Version: go1.7
Operating System: linux
GOPATH=
GOROOT=/usr/local/go
```
OS & Version: Linux

#### Expected behaviour
JSON RPC should respond to requests

#### Actual behaviour
**While running 1.7.0**:
At 19:16 UTC on October 4th, 2017, we started getting erratic responses from geth's JSON RPC. It basically just failed to respond. We were able to consistently reproduce by calling `eth_getBalance` for random addresses in a loop: geth was intermittent at responding.

Roughly at 19:46 UTC on October 4th, 2017 the problems subsided and geth's jsonRPC started acting normally again. We didn't see any problems until....

At 01:20 UTC on October 5th, 2017 we **updated to geth 1.7.1**. Immediately after updating we started seeing erratic behavior from geth's JSON RPC while under normal operations. We have been unable to pinpoint what is exactly the problem, but downgrading to 1.7.0 seems to have helped.

#### Steps to reproduce the behaviour
Uncertain at this point.

#### Backtrace

````
[backtrace]
````
We just added logic to retry when there are errors and sleep in between retries. This seems to have really helped, but still worth mentioning the problem.

I can confirm we have also seen erratic behaviour after upgrading directly to 1.7.1 (we were using the version prior to 1.7.0). Nothing that can be repeated constantly but we have had transactions sent that didn't give transaction ID and when that's the case, the code should display the error that occured. We had a few "authentication needed: password or unlock" - but before you tell me that the account needs to be unlocked, the code has not changed and we only saw this error since the upgrade to 1.7.1.
Some other times we simply had no error, leading me to believe the script ended abruptly.

Nothing in the geth logs for any of these occurrences.

Would be interesting to know more about the error. I'd expect there to be a json rpc error response, containing more details about the error. 
Can you check if you are logging error-messages returned by the API, @vogelito ?
Perhaps the node was overloaded disk wise? 1.7.x does a database upgrade that can be quite heavy, especially if done under a production server that also hammers the disk.
We had the "deduplicating database entries" running at the same time - could it be related?
That is very heavy on the disk, yes.
Ok that would explain our issue - however @vogelito was running 1.7.0 for a while so his situation is different. Ours is running fine at the moment but will keep an eye on things. Thanks

Can confirm seeing lots of issues with account unlock and failing RPC with 1.7.1.

1.7.0 working without issues.
1.7.1 contains just a handful of bugfixes, none whatsoever touches account handling. Could you please provide some additional infos on what "failing" consists of?

Similar to what is reported above.

1.7.1 is considered unusable with the RPC issues. /me represents one of the larger exchanges.

Is this commit sufficient to back port?
https://github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/commit/7514e8a24d3dc332e58be4b26f893aff8c24a9e7

You'll need the gas estimation fix https://github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/pull/15030 and the log filter fix https://github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/pull/15195 too at least.

That being said, I'm really missing what might happen, would really appreciate actual logs or detailed behavior. Saying "similar to above" doesn't really help us debug the issue.
Executed the same test on both HTTP RPC and WebSocket RPC, both functioned properly until I terminated them after 100K iterations.

@holiman apologies for the late reply. It's been a hectic day. We log all responses from geth but this time there are no errors being returned by the JSON RPC - it just fails to respond and drops the connection. I can confirm that I had been running 1.7.0 for days (so we had already done the db upgrade) without issues and **we first saw the error while still on 1.7.0**. Upgrading to 1.7.1 seems to have made it worse so we returned to 1.7.0 and the problem went away. For the past 12 hours we have been running 1.7.1 again and have not seen the error once. Looking at our disk latency graphs, I can confirm that these errors are 100% correlated with disk latency issues and unusually high outbound network traffic. The only thing we are running on this box is geth. Digging through the geth logs I don't see anything unusual around the times of the high latency... @karalabe - I can no longer reproduce the connection drops.

Here are my disk latency graphs for: past month (you can see the db upgrade on the 17th): Past week: Past 2 days: Past 24 hours: We're still working on our data collection/monitoring infrastructure, but the data points are currently getting interpolated so they lose resolution as we increase the time windows.
Those who are having problems; do you have massive number of wallet/accounts? I'm curious if this is related to https://github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/issues/14810
What is massive? We have in the low hundreds of thousands.

Yeah, that's pretty massive. Could it be that you were creating new accounts when you ran into these issues? (either through the RPC or by placing new files within the `keystore`) .

The issues may be timeouts on the socket connections. I still think there should be some caller-side exception telling you what occurred though, but not a json rpc error message.

We do also log all the responses coming out of Geth and that's how I got the few errors about the unlocking of accounts. However, in some instances, we received nothing from Geth at all. As @vogelito mentioned, it looks as though the connection was simply dropped.

It all happened on the 4th starting at roughly 13:50 UTC - right after the upgrade to 1.7.1 - so disk usage was high due to the database migration. However, this fact is inconsistent with Daniel's issue as he was on 1.7.0 and had done the DB upgrade on the 17th of September.

I am happy to report that we have had no issues at all for at least 36 hours now.
As far as we are concerned, we have about 30K accounts on our system - don't think that's considered massive.

The problem repeated this morning at 8:19AM local time (see graphs below) while running 1.7.1. I can confirm no new accounts were being created at the time. Attaching graphs. I'm beginning to think it's actually a CPU issue. The geth log at the time we started noticing errors only shows `Imported new chain segment` and `Submitted transaction` messages in no unusual manner.
We *just* upgraded to 1.7.2 and we're seeing an important spike of intermittency with the JSON RPC. CPU and load increased importantly and matches time of upgrade:

Is there peering preference for same version nodes? Our bytes sent metric has 200x'ed since updating the node (we updated very soon after geth release). This could explain why last time downgrading to 1.7.0 seems to have helped. Once we went back to 1.7.1 there were probably enough nodes that ours wasn't particularly overloaded.
Just FYI - 1.7.x seems to be a lot more CPU intensive. The spike in CPU matches exactly our upgrade to 1.7.0

Not as pretty as @vogelito but I think it speaks for itself. Server was down about 30s time to stop and start the new compiled code.
![geth - 3 hours](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6663671/31579514-ee3027a4-b12f-11e7-9ad9-351dcc7d5b47.png)
![geth - 1 hour](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6663671/31579513-ee16587e-b12f-11e7-9b64-b2898a7d029f.png)

What `cache` option are you using? 

It takes a while before the cache "gets warm". And larger cache means that it takes longer before it reaches it's maximum 'warmth', where it probably was right before you switched off the node. 

Please let us know how it looks after some time has passed; a few hours, or a day or so.

`--cache 3072`
And yes, it has now settled back down and is running smoothly.

`--cache 1024` CPU/load seems much higher in `1.7.x` Last 2 months CPU/load: Disk latency seems much better (the spike is the upgrade): To compare with the graphs in [prior post](https://github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/issues/15243#issuecomment-336635488), this is the last hour graph for CPU/load (still on `1.7.2`):
We're no longer seeing this issue, so closing.
